response:
To find the value of $\left(\frac{1+i}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{46}$, we can start by expressing $\frac{1+i}{\sqrt{2}}$ in polar form.

We have that $\frac{1+i}{\sqrt{2}} = \cos \left(45^\circ\right) + i \sin \left(45^\circ\right)$.

Now, using De Moivre's theorem, we can raise this to the power of $46$: 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left(\frac{1+i}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{46} \\ &= \left[\cos \left(45^\circ\right) + i \sin \left(45^\circ\right)\right]^{46}\\ 
&= \cos\left(45^{\circ}\cdot 46\right)+i \sin\left(45^{\circ}\cdot 46\right)\\
&=\cos \left(2070^{\circ} \right)+i \sin\left(2070^{\circ}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, we can simplify this by observing that $2070 = 5.4 \times 360 + 270$, and since $\sin (270^\circ)=-1$ and $\cos(270^\circ)=0$, 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&= \cos \left(2070^{\circ}\right)+i \sin \left(2070^{\circ}\right)\\ 
&= \cos (5.4\times 360 + 270) + i\sin(5.4\times 360+270) \\
&=\cos(270^\circ) + i\sin(270^\circ)\\
&=0 + i(-1)\\
&=-i.
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\left(\frac{1+i}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^{46} = -i$
